text.author: Michiel Cock, Lotte Wilms
text.title: Digital Humanities Clinics - Leading Dutch Librarians into DH
text.summary1: (human1) This poster paper presents a plan to hold up to six Digital Humanities (DH) clinics, one day events which include lectures and hands-on training, to help Dutch librarians in the Netherlands and Belgium to provide researchers and students with services and follow literature and research in the area of DH.
text.summary2: (human2) In 2016, the National Library of the Netherlands and the University Library of the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam joined forces to develop a set of clinics on DH for librarians in order to teach librarians the ins and outs of DH in order for them to take up their natural role of facilitating and supporting research and ideally become the research partner needed in DH projects.
text.summary3: (human3) In 2015, Dutch academic institutions launched an initiative to provide basic methodological competencies and technical skills to a diverse group of librarians to help them gain key skills in Digital Humanities and, subsequently, to promote higher accessibility for new digital scholars at Dutch universities.
text.summary4: (human4) Researchers describe the need for Dutch librarians to gain exposure to and competence with Digital Humanities resources, and then describe the ongoing process of designing and implementing these courses to create a six-course program for Dutch librarians.
text.summary5: (human5) This paper describes the 2015 initiative to start a Dutch Digital Humanities (DH) and Librarian community in the Netherlands and Belgium, by developing DH clinics and curriculum for librarians to provide them with methodological and technical training so they can later become research partners in DH projects.
